{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3320292,"name":"Asher Olgeirson","username":"Cynosure","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cynosure/{size}/184875_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-29T03:56:14.233Z","cooked":"

So I am under the impression that frc2::CommandPtr has has a delete constructor for rvalues (frc2::CommandPtr()&&=delete;) and that this prevents methods from being called on rvalue CommandPtrs (such as return values). However, what were the design decisions behind doing this and what’s the advantage of this.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-02-29T03:56:14.233Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":29,"reads":62,"readers_count":61,"score":157.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":456634,"topic_slug":"why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues","display_username":"Asher Olgeirson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51179,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues/456634/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3320338,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-29T05:18:59.362Z","cooked":"

Not quite, here’s the truncated CommandPtr header.

class CommandPtr final {
 public:
  explicit CommandPtr(std::unique_ptr<Command>&& command);

  template <std::derived_from<Command> T>
  // NOLINTNEXTLINE(bugprone-forwarding-reference-overload)
  explicit CommandPtr(T&& command)
      : CommandPtr(
            std::make_unique<std::decay_t<T>>(std::forward<T>(command))) {}

  CommandPtr(CommandPtr&&);
  CommandPtr& operator=(CommandPtr&&) = default;

  explicit CommandPtr(std::nullptr_t) = delete;

...
[[nodiscard]]
  CommandPtr AndThen(std::function<void()> toRun,
                     Requirements requirements = {}) &&;

  [[nodiscard]]
  CommandPtr AndThen(CommandPtr&& next) &&;

The only deleted constructor here is from a nullptr.

Otherwise, the ONLY way to construct a CommandPtr is from an rvalue reference.

Further, as you can see, the decorator methods they’ve defined have the “&&” qualifier after them.
This means that these methods can ONLY be called on an rvalue.

That means you’re allowed to do this

CommandPtr aim_and_shoot = MakeAimCommand().AndThen(MakeShootCommand());

but not this

CommandPtr aim = MakeAimCommand();
CommandPtr shoot = MakeShootCommand();
CommandPtr aim_and_shoot = aim.AndThen(shoot);

but you COULD do this

CommandPtr aim = MakeAimCommand();
CommandPtr shoot = MakeShootCommand();
CommandPtr aim_and_shoot = std::move(aim).AndThen(std::move(shoot));
// aim/shoot variables are invalid after this ^

The reason for this is that when you call the decorators, under the hood a new command is created which now owns the original command.

If they allowed the second case to work, people might be confused if they did this:

aim.AndThen(shoot);

They may think that aim is now augmented to have shoot run after it, when in actuality a new command with a new underlying type needs to be created.

The design behind the new commands is that you’re meant to ONLY be able to interface with them via method chaining. Once you store it in a variable, it should not be able to be augmented unless you explicitly move from that variable.

This allows for the declarative style of programming that they’re striving for in the modern command library.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-02-29T05:18:59.362Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":56,"readers_count":55,"score":31.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":456634,"topic_slug":"why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues/456634/2","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3320344,"name":"Minh Le","username":"bun6502","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bun6502/{size}/217690_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-29T05:26:17.390Z","cooked":"

I would like to add, having used C++ in last year’s code, the question of how to save commands for reuse/multiuse. I remember saving a command in a variable so I could augment it in different ways for different variations, or storing the commands in a SendableChooser and retrieving them later. But I could never quite get it to work right without some workarounds because you must use rvalues, and I would get use-after-move errors when I tried to std::move them.

While I get the reasoning behind this declarative style of programming, and appreciate it somewhat, the limitations can be quite bothersome, and are the main reason I learned Java this year just so I could use it instead. Is there a way to reuse commands like this instead of having to generate a new one each time?

(Also, I haven’t checked carefully, but doesn’t Java let you do these things even though C++ doesn’t?)

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-02-29T05:26:17.390Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":37,"readers_count":36,"score":12.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":456634,"topic_slug":"why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues","display_username":"Minh Le","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64664,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues/456634/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3320358,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-29T05:50:54.572Z","cooked":"

You should not reuse the same command instances in different places. We can’t prevent this in Java, but because commands can/do have internal state, it breaks things to reuse them.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-02-29T05:51:40.205Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":31,"readers_count":30,"score":11.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":456634,"topic_slug":"why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues/456634/4","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3320359,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-29T05:51:02.986Z","cooked":"
FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

A Technical Discussion on C++ Commands

This article will help you understand the reasoning behind some of the decisions made in the 2020 command-based framework (such as the use of std::unique_ptr, CRTP in the form of CommandHelper

They discuss this at length in this article.
It boils down to the memory model being different in Java and C++.

To be honest, now that I’ve read through it, I sort of agree that I don’t understand the philosophy. They could have made it act like Java if they used shared_ptr.

In this article the say this on using shared_ptr:

With std::shared_ptr , there is no clear ownership model because there can be multiple instances of a std::shared_ptr that point to the same block of memory. If commands were in std::shared_ptr instances, a command group or the command scheduler cannot take ownership and free the memory once the command has finished executing because the user might still unknowingly still have a std::shared_ptr instance pointing to that block of memory somewhere in scope.

This doesn’t really make a lot of sense to me, surely 99% of people generate commands at init time and bind them to triggers or auton modes. Rarely are you actually instantiating new commands while the robot is driving and having a lot of memory to clean up.

Maybe the WPILib developers who frequent this forum can shed more insight.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-02-29T06:01:23.735Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":29,"readers_count":28,"score":20.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":456634,"topic_slug":"why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/commandbased/cpp-command-discussion.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"A Technical Discussion on C++ Commands — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":64664,"username":"bun6502","name":"Minh Le","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bun6502/{size}/217690_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues/456634/5","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3320360,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-29T05:54:53.383Z","cooked":"

Ah, I had an inkling it might be related to this, but then I thought “well if it works in Java then surely that’s not the case.”

Honestly I can’t really imagine a lot of cases where this comes up either, since commands are usually associated with subsystems, it seems rare that the same command could be scheduled multiple times simultaneously, no?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-02-29T05:54:53.383Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":29,"readers_count":28,"score":5.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":456634,"topic_slug":"why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13575,"username":"Peter_Johnson","name":"Peter Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues/456634/6","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3320520,"name":"Asher Olgeirson","username":"Cynosure","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cynosure/{size}/184875_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-29T14:38:28.195Z","cooked":"

Okay, that makes sense. Thanks for the great response. However doesn’t the .schedule() method require lvalues, or do all methods explicitly need rvalues?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-02-29T14:38:28.195Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":22,"readers_count":21,"score":9.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":456634,"topic_slug":"why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues","display_username":"Asher Olgeirson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":35208,"username":"bathtubed","name":"Eric Ward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51179,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/why-can-you-only-call-frc2-commandptr-methods-on-lvalues-and-not-rvalues/456634/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3320629,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-29T16:05:11.476Z","cooked":"

Yep! So all the decorators which augment how the commands work use R-values for the declarative method chaining technique.
But the methods which actually call the commands (schedule, cancel, etc) are allowed to be used on either value type, since these feasibly can be getting called after initialization time, and they don’t actually change what the command does or how it’s memory is managed.

And if you look at CommandPtr.h you can see methods like schedule don’t have the “&&” qualifier after them.
